awd_titl_txt: CAREER: MULTIPHASE FLUID-MATERIAL INTERACTION: CAVITATION MODELING AND DAMAGE ASSESSMENT
awd_abstract_narration:
Cavitation describes the formation, growth, and violent collapse of bubbles in a liquid when exposed to rapid pressure variations. If carefully controlled, cavitation can be a unique approach for high-precision material modification and fabrication, as it allows high-intensity energy pulses to be generated safely, released remotely, and focused within a small target region. The goal of this project is to understand how cavitation affects solid materials close to the bubbles; and to use this knowledge to be able to predict how cavitation modifies nearby material. The proposed research will provide new scientific insight for a broad range of engineering and biomedical applications, from fabricating materials to curing diseases. The educational and outreach component of the project will directly impact the education of K-12 schoolchildren in Central and Western Virginia, through collaboration with the Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity at Virginia Tech and the Science Museum of Western Virginia in Roanoke, VA.

Previous research on cavitation has primarily focused on either the fluid part of the problem, without considering the material's response, or the material part, particularly the macroscopic fracture (e.g., pits, cracks, holes) after multiple cycles of bubble collapse. This project will start with developing and experimentally validating a computational fluid dynamics/computational solid dynamics - coupled model, which will enable direct numerical simulation of up to hundreds of bubbles interacting with a broad range of materials, including fluid-induced damage and fracture. Next, the comprehensive characterization of single bubbles, tandem bubbles, and small bubble clusters collapsing near various materials will create a theoretical foundation for clarifying the micro-scale mechanisms underlying cavitation-induced material damage. Further, the direct numerical simulation model will be used to examine simplified bubbly flow models and, in combination with machine learning, design new models with improved predictive capability.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In January 2018, Virginia Tech was awarded a Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) grant for the project titled “Multiphase Fluid-Material Interaction: Cavitation Modeling and Damage Assessment,” with Dr. Kevin Wang serving as the principal investigator (PI). In general, cavitation refers to the formation of bubbles in a liquid due to changes in pressure or temperature. It is a critical phenomenon in many engineering and medical applications, with both beneficial and detrimental implications depending on the context. This project aimed to advance the understanding of cavitation and enhance predictive modeling capabilities for bubble formation and their two-way interactions with surrounding hard and soft materials. During the project period, progresses have been achieved in three primary areas, which are outlined below.

Development of Models, Algorithms, and Software: A comprehensive computational model was developed, integrating multiphase fluid dynamics with the dynamics of nearby solid and soft materials. The model was further extended to include laser absorption and laser-fluid coupling effects, utilizing a novel numerical method called the latent heat reservoir for simulating laser-induced cavitation. Additionally, improvements were made to existing numerical methods for simulating multiphase compressible flows, particularly by optimizing the computation of advection fluxes across material interfaces to enhance efficiency. These advancements were implemented in open-source research codes and subjected to verification and validation studies. As part of this effort, a new software, M2C (Multiphysics Modeling and Computation), was developed, integrating the features mentioned above into a unified tool for multiphysics simulations.

Two-Way Interaction Between Cavitation Bubbles and Deformable Materials: A computational parametric study was conducted to explore the damage caused by cavitation bubble collapse on various hard and soft materials, including metals, non-metallic minerals/rocks, and biological tissues. The results revealed that such damage cannot be accurately predicted by analyzing bubble dynamics alone; instead, it arises from a transient interaction among the bubble, the surrounding liquid, and the material. Furthermore, the study identified the acoustic impedance of the material as a key factor dictating this interaction.

Laser-Fluid Coupling and Laser-Induced Vaporization: The mechanisms underlying the formation of non-spherical vapor bubbles generated by long-pulsed lasers in liquids were investigated using a combination of laboratory experiments and numerical simulations. The findings demonstrated that variations in laser wavelength, energy, and power profile can trigger transitions between rounded and elongated bubbles. Simulations indicated that this transition is primarily driven by the interplay between bubble growth due to advection and continued vaporization. These results provide valuable insights into the complex interactions between laser radiation, phase transitions, and fluid dynamics during vapor bubble formation.

The project also contributed to educational initiatives. Dr. Wang developed two new graduate-level courses at Virginia Tech: Fluid-Structure Interaction and Numerical Methods for Aerospace and Ocean Engineering. Additionally, he created a workshop titled “The Power and Beauty of Little Bubbles,” designed to introduce high school and undergraduate students to the phenomenon and physics of cavitation. This workshop has been delivered multiple times at various summer camps organized by Virginia Tech and during an outreach event organized by the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE).

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2024
Modified by: Kevin Wang

The project also contributed to educational initiatives. Dr. Wang developed two new graduate-level courses at Virginia Tech: Fluid-Structure Interaction and Numerical Methods for Aerospace and Ocean Engineering.
